Award.AwardTitle: An Experimental Evaluation of a Matching Market Mechanism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Over the last three decades, insights from market design have had a tremendous impact on<br/>matching markets without prices. Economists have helped re-design the mechanisms for<br/>matching new doctors to hospitals, for assigning students to schools in a number of large school<br/>districts, and for optimally matching kidney donors to recipients. Despite the apparent success of<br/>market design in these markets, there is remarkably little empirical evidence of the impact of<br/>these reforms on market and match outcomes. This project will provide the most credible<br/>evidence to date of the impact of matching using a common market design mechanism on match<br/>outcomes in the context of matching Army officers to positions. Each year, over ten thousand<br/>officers apply for transfers to new units within the military. This project will measure the impact<br/>of using a common market design algorithm or the status quo mechanism on match outcomes,<br/>like officers’ retention and performance.<br/><br/>Each year, over ten thousand officers apply for transfers to new units within the military.<br/>Currently, this officer to unit matching is implemented manually by the US Army’s Human<br/>Resources Command (HRC). This project uses a randomized controlled trial to measure the<br/>impact of replacing the status quo assignment process with the deferred acceptance algorithm on<br/>match outcomes, like officers’ retention and performance. Specifically, disjoint markets, defined<br/>by officers’ rank and specialization (e.g. Captains in engineering) were randomly assigned to<br/>determine matches using either the deferred acceptance algorithm or the status quo mechanism.<br/>This will provide the first evidence from a randomized controlled trial about the impact of a<br/>market design intervention on match and market outcomes.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
